reviewText:
Okay, nice game, great premise and a nice little twist on a FNAF clone. It makes it kind of original.
Pros:
- Great monster.
- Nice Graphics.
- The game is meticulous about objectives etc. and does provide helpful tutorials.
- Generally nice premise and quite scary with some heavy jumpscares and a good atmosphere.

Cons:
- It's simplicity is nice, but it's a bit too simple. I get that it costs so cheap, but I would like to see some expansion on the content even if it means an increase in price. Let me put it like this: The game has a solid foundation, but not really that much on it. I wish the developer would play, experiment and expand on some features of the game like Sophie for example. She is only used for jumpscares (she does try new tactics later on), but my point is, the developer can do a bit more with her. He can probably add a few gamemodes as well
- The game doesn't really have that much cons, which is great, but the game could do with a bit more story and context as well, but this point could be entirely optional.
I could go on for hours about pros and cons about the game.

I would give this game a 7/10. I was going to go with 6/10, but then I just thought about what this game would become later and I just sticked with 7, hell it might even become an 8 later on. Also the game does improve as the hours progress. Well done Luis Contreras :)

UPDATE
I've changed my negative review to a positive one on account of the developer making such a focused effort to respond to my criticisms of the game outlined in my original review below.

The random deaths, which were the one very major issue I had with Sophie's Curse, are no longer in the game. Some people are disappointed with that but, personally, I don't see what joy there is to be gained from failing for absolutely no reason, especially in a title where the action is spread relatively thin in the early stages.

The 'jumpscare simulator' will never be a favourite sub-genre for me but, with the issues addressed, this is about as solid an example of one as you can hope to find on Steam.

=======================================================
Original Review
Sorry to be the lone voice of dissent here but... no. Not while we're rating this as an actual playable game.

The premise is simple enough. You've got four lights to keep on, two upstairs and two downstairs, while avoiding the titular ghoul Sophie who will sneak, scuttle and slither around behind you at all times, looking for the perfect moment to grab your face and howl at it with a decibel count to rival most mid-40's war artillery.

The problem is that there's no rhyme or reason as to when she can murder you and when she can't. You're assigned a safe point at the start of the game that changes around between checkpoints but it's about as much use as nipples on a tank. By the developer's own admission, and I quote:

If Sophie doesn’t like you she might kill you randomly but this is very very rare

I saw Youtubers play this and thought it looks and feels like the game I'd like so bought it.  There's a lot of tension and getting ready for a jumpscare and the jumpscare itself is good.  However, I found myself walking through the game up to 12am and only lost because the I was using the computer when the system crashed and within a split second of the scren going down Sophie jumped me from zone A and never stood a chance.  Second jumpscare was when I went downstairs and immediately got jumpscared as she was standing over by B.  I'm now all the way up to 2:30am but only played 40 minutes of the game.  I'm not sure if the game gets harder or not but it seems like the win/lose is based on random luck being caught out by mechanics like above which I have no chance of avoiding.  The youtubers made this look and feel harder than it actually is though I read that there has been some work on the game probably since they played it.  I also have a bit of trouble identifying where to click.  While there is a tutorial at the start I wasn't sure if I could flick the camera to turn or to just click there and where was clickable if I could.

I had another go and got to just after 3am and once again the instant the system started shutting down I got jumpscared.  The only times I'm getting jumpscared is when I literally can't avoid it so on the one hand it's super easy but on the other it's annoyingly difficult and frustrating.  One problem I have with the mechanics (though not a bug) is this;  When the power goes down you go to wind them up but as the night goes on the system crashes more and more.  Provided that you can get through the crashes the system literally reboots itself for you and this looks to happen more and more frequently meaning it's more the challenge of surviving the crashes and making sure none of the lights go out.

I can tell the game is getting harder but within an hour of playing I feel like I'm going to beat this game too easily and the only way I won't is jumpscares I have no way of avoiding.  This game has lots of potential buti it has some issues which I hope I've given constructive feedback on and hope it helps make a better game.  Can't say whether to recommend this game or not it's hard to say....I can't submit otherwise so I'd say...no but for people to watch this space and wait for the issues to be ironed out.  All the best, there definitely potential here.  Maybe more backstory or lore to the game would be good as well.

Sophie's Curse...
Something to obiously take into consideration, the game was made by  only a single person  which, in my opinion, its really surprising, and he made a great job.

Alot of people compare it with  Five Night At Freddy's , and  Emily Wants To Play  which, yeah, they share some similarities, but even after that, this game owns some interesting mechanics.

Im not a spoopy games player, i like to play them, but im most likely going to throw my controller (Or headphones in this case) in the moment i hear something, or something goes to ♥♥♥♥.
Why im saying this?, i legit threw my headphones and walked out the room...  (Like a pu$$y)

Back to the main topic
The plot of the game is; you accepted the job of taking care of a old man, making sure he's fine while he's asleep and check if he needs something in the night.

But there's the thing, the house is old, and it doesent have electricity by itself, thankfully the guy who requested the job, had the great idea of making tiny machines that can make electricity

It should be ok then?... RIGHT?!

Well, turns out since the machine its still a prototype, and its not flawless...
The machines can malfunction, and you have to turn them back on, you can make that, by going to a laptop and solving the *puzzle* (As seen in the trailer)

There's 4 machines (Or Checkpoints)  in total  A,B,C,D. 2 on the first floor and other ones in the second floor.
You have to make sure they always have some power to function and make sure they dont crash while dark...

TL;DR The game owns some really good mechanics, and i highly recommend it, its scary and it can last some time before you can actually learn the mechanics, plus its helping this new developer, soo he can make more games, and even better!.

If you want to check another project of this developer, search for  Grey Night  (Which sadly was cancelled for the lack of support and time)

My love for Indie horror games and such has led me to every corner of steam trying to find new good games to play and support and this one grabbed my attention the day it was released!

Sophie's Curse uses human being's natural fear of the unkown and possibly one of the most terrifying ambiances I have ever seen in all my years of gaming.

The Story

As it stands right now, you are the caretaker of an old man (who is fast asleep throughout the night) and you have to stay there and watch over him. Every 2 hours there is a checkpoint saving your progress as you go onto each 2 hour interval. The only form of electricity are four small hand-cranked devices that you spin to keep the battery from running out, occasionally the machines fail and have to be restarted via the laptop in the kitchen. All the while something isnt right with the house, an angry spirit for reasons unknown wants your booty and you have to keep the lights on and stay in the designated safe zone" whenever possible to avoid getting your booty torn open by said spirit.

reviewText:
If you are not a fan of Jumpscare games than this game might not be for you.
If you enjoyed games like FnaF, Boogeyman or Emily Wants to Play then you probably will enjoy Sophie's Curse as well.

You are a Nurse who is to take care of an old man in a house which has no electricity for 1 night. The lights in this house are powered by a crank that needs to be manually turned to re-generate as they loose power over time, or are interfered with by Sophie.

While it uses FnaF like mechanics I really enjoy that you walk" around the house to different rooms
date:
rather than being in a single room. It is not open roaming like Emily wants to play but instead clicking areas on the screen makes you walk to different rooms.

You only have to survive a single night but the night is divided into sections of 2 hours. Each 2 hours you survive will save that checkpoint to continue from.

Your Job is to ensure that the lamps keep staying bright by manual turning the handles on their generators to replenish their power. There is 4 lights
hoursPlayed:
with 1 randomly being chosen to the be a "savepoint" when thinks get hairy.

As you progress through the night things get more frantic with each checkpoint with lamps not only loosing power but starting to fail completely needing you to use your laptop in the kitchen to re-activate them and solve additional tasks to do so.

Listen out for queues to know when to stop powering lights

reviewText:
Overall Review - Pretty damn scary

Story
In Sophie's Curse, you play as an unnamed woman who takes the job as a nurse. As the nurse, you must take care of an elder who just recently purchased a new house. This new house being the one Sophie haunts. To survive, you must manually keep the light sources active by exploring the house to crank the generators individually.

Backstory
Sophie was a young and average teenage girl with a great GPA. But out of nowhere, she went missing.

Gameplay
Not the best graphics, but that doesn't really matter. The concept is pretty nice. It differs from what seems to be similar to the FNaF franchise according to the community's responses. The AI of Sophie isn't bugged or anything. The game carries in a lot of scares. Through and through, the game is pretty well done.

Pros
- Spooky
- Challenging

Cons
- Long nights

Through and through, I'd recommend this game to people who are interested in horror games.
